docs.lead_paragraph: When Benjamin Brody awoke from abdominal surgery, he was groggy and disoriented. As he slid back his surgical gown to take a look at his new incision, he did not see the usual cross-hatching of sutures or the minirailroad track of staples. Instead, he saw a zipper. ''I thought, 'Oh, my God, what is this?' '' he recalled recently. ''I had never seen anything like it in my life.''

headline.main: Zipping Up: A Substitute For Stitches And Staples

docs.abstract: Atrax Medical Group Ltd develops surgical zipper, called a Medizip, as alternative to sutures and staples; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Dementia strikes four million Americans every year, according to the American Medical Association, sapping their memories and their ability to live independently. Most commonly a result of Alzheimer's disease, it grows ever more prevalent as the population grows older: the association says 35 percent to 45 percent of people over 85 have it to at least some degree.

headline.main: Dementia, Or Simply Old Age? A Guidebook

docs.abstract: American Medical Association publishes booklet on diagnosing, managing and treating dementia, a condition that it says afflicts 35 percent to 45 percent of people over 85 to at least some degree (M)
docs.snippet: Dementia strikes four million Americans every year, according to the American Medical Association, sapping their memories and their ability to live independently.     Most commonly a result of Alzheimer's disease, it grows ever more prevalent as the...

docs.lead_paragraph: Black patients with broken arms or legs were less likely to be given painkillers in an Atlanta emergency room than white patients with similar injuries and complaints of pain, a new study has found. Researchers at Emory University School of Medicine in Atlanta examined the charts of 127 black patients and 90 white patients who were treated by 37 doctors at the hospital, which was not identified, from 1992 to 1995. They found that 43 percent of black patients with fractures of the extremities received no pain medication in the emergency room, while 26 percent of white patients with similar injuries went untreated for pain. The study appears in the January issue of The Annals of Emergency Medicine.

headline.main: In Treating Patients for Pain, a Racial Gap

docs.abstract: Researchers at Emory University School of Medicine report that black patients with broken arms or legs are less likely to be given painkillers in an Atlanta emergency room than white patients with similar injuries and complaints of pain; Dr Lewis R Goldfrank, director of emergency services at Bellevue Hospital Center in Manhattan, says different treatment is due to racism (M)
docs.snippet: Black patients with broken arms or legs were less likely to be given painkillers in an Atlanta emergency room than white patients with similar injuries and complaints of pain, a new study has found.     Researchers at Emory University School of...

docs.lead_paragraph: They come at you from magazine covers and video advertisements in particular profusion in this season of the New Year's resolution: the perfect-looking people who promise ''sexy thighs in six minutes a day'' or ''the body of your dreams.'' It's as easy, they say, as buying this machine, following that diet or doing another exercise. But for anyone alienated by these impossibly hard-bodied role models, another approach is fast catching on: fitness programs led by people who need to diet themselves.

headline.main: Role Models for Fitness Now Come in Super Sizes

docs.abstract: Rosie O'Donnell's Chub Club is only the best known of a growing number of fitness programs that are not led by people with perfect-looking bodies; experts in weight control and physical activity welcome development, saying it may encourage more overweight and out-of-shape people to exercise and give them reasonable goals; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In Marseille, France, some vending machines dispense neither soda nor candy but free sterile needles for drug users. In Vancouver, British Columbia, a stack of colorful coupons sits next to the register at a local drugstore, offering 10 percent off on condoms. The two endeavors aim to block the spread of infectious diseases, especially AIDS, by making preventive tools available to people who might be reluctant to seek them out in clinics or doctors' offices. And two studies in the December issue of The American Journal of Public Health suggest that they are working.

headline.main: Vending Machines Enlisted in AIDS Fight

docs.abstract: Two studies affirm effectiveness of vending machines in helping to block spread of infectious diseases, AIDS in particular; they make preventive tools like sterile needles and condoms available to people who might be reluctant to seek them out in clinics or doctors' offices (M)
docs.snippet: In Marseille, France, some vending machines dispense neither soda nor candy but free sterile needles for drug users. In Vancouver, British Columbia, a stack of colorful coupons sits next to the register at a local drugstore, offering 10 percent off...

docs.lead_paragraph: There is probably no time of year when America's sleep debt is greater than it is right now. Starting with Thanksgiving week, holiday preparations and parties, gift shopping and packaging, family visits and extra hours of work to make up for days off prompt millions of Americans to cheat on their sleep even more than usual. Many are used to being tired and think, optimistically, that they'll catch up with lost sleep after the New Year. But few do. And new research suggests that the consequences of chronic sleep deprivation may be far worse than simply diminished mental sharpness, shortened tempers and a tendency to doze off at every quiet moment. Rather, sleep scientists at the University of Chicago found that those who suffer from an accumulated sleep debt may develop serious health problems, including obesity, diabetes and high blood pressure.

headline.main: Paying the Price for Cheating on Sleep

docs.abstract: First of two Jane E Brody columns on sleep debt discusses research on consequences of chronic sleep deprivation, which can be a serious as obesity, diabetes and high blood pressure; says a study has also found that as little as a weeklong sleep debt of three or four hours a night has adverse effects on body's ability to process carbohydrates, manage stress, maintain a proper balance of hormones and fight off infection; drawing (M)
